ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to think more deeply and better close read a text. My writing skills were also developed in this course. This class helped me learn how to better write an essay and more purposefully use my language and format of the paper to my advantage in pushing an argument forward. I also gained many insights from the texts we engaged with, the instructor, and my peers on the topics explored in science fiction and their relation to Asian American identity.
I developed my skills as a writer, specifically strengthening my ability to close in on a specific topic and stay within the scope of the paper.

Improved analysis on pieces of literature relating to Asian American identity or Sci-fi genres. Additionally, practiced writing essays with a thesis statement and utilizing the Yale library to find research journals or articles that can aid in our writing.

- how to write a complicated, insightful college essay
- how to peer review and peer edit
- how to manage a heavy reading load and organize time
- how to engage thoughtfully, respectfully, and passionately with other students
- how to ask for help and get helpful feedback

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: great reading material, and variety of other media that we discuss in this course
Weakness: I wish there was more technical feedback on assignments

Due to the nature of this course being a literature seminar, the readings each week could be heavy if not managed properly, but the instructor also adjusted accordingly to our feedback throughout the seminar and lightened the workload when she sensed we would benefit from it. The assigned papers were well distributed throughout the semester, and I think they were assigned at appropriate times to allow us to continuously develop our writing skills. The discussions were one of the greatest strengths of the class; the time was well spent discussing various aspects of the texts we read, and all students were well engaged (the instructor also worked to ensure engagement was high among all students).

A strength that I enjoyed was the level of comfort with which everyone could speak and how unique yet familiar the readings were (often a book or supplemental reading was new to most of the class, but there was always someone who had prior knowledge or insight adding to the discussions).

This course allowed for students with like-minded attitudes on the topics of hybrid identities and intricacy of sci-fi to come together in one room and discuss the endless questions that are developed within the passages. It allows the student to develop critical thinking and analysis while learning to express their opinions and building it off of others. This small section garnered a connection between students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if you like fiction stories

I would highly recommend this course to another student because the discussions are very insightful, especially if one is interested in Asian American Identities and science fiction (as the name of the course suggests). Moreover, the instructor gives well articulated, constructive feedback on writing, which is helpful in developing those skills.
Yes, the course was well organized and the feedback was clear and helpful and following it directly lead to visible improvements.

Yes, I would recommend this course especially if you enjoy hearing other perspectives to enrich yours. While this course is specifically titled "Asian-American identity," this complicated topic can be touched upon many different identities. Additionally, it is a great writing credit that allows you to strengthen your writing ability without writing significant numbers of papers.
YES YES YES YES YES!!!! Helen is a wonderful professor, and everything you learn in this class will stick with you. Befriend your classmates, too: the class works best when you're all friends.
